description: A futuristic architectural marvel shaped like a rhombicuboctahedron (an Archimedean solid with 8 triangular and 18 square faces), the National Library of Belarus opened in 2006 and has become Minsk's most iconic modern landmark. Standing 73.6 meters tall and weighing 115,000 tonnes, this diamond-shaped building houses 8 million items and transforms into a spectacular LED light show at night with over 4,646 color-changing fixtures creating dynamic displays visible from miles away.
highlights: Observation deck at 73 meters height with panoramic views of Minsk accessed via transparent glass elevator
Spectacular nighttime LED light show with 4,646 fixtures creating over 20 different schemes using 65,000+ colors
Book Museum containing over 300 unique manuscripts including Bibles printed by Belarusian pioneer Frantsisk Skorina (1517-1519)
World's third largest collection of Russian books with 10 million total items
Unique rhombicuboctahedron architecture featured in '100 Most Surprising Achievements of Modern Architecture' alongside Gaudi's works
International Meeting Center that has hosted CIS state summits
Capacity for over 2,000 readers simultaneously with 500-seat conference hall
tips: Bring your passport - it's required to enter the main building
Visit at night to see the spectacular LED light show, best viewed from surrounding parks
Take the metro to Vostok station on Line 1 for fastest access
Enter around the back of the building to access the observation deck on the 23rd floor
The observation deck is worth 20 minutes max - don't expect pristine views as glass can be dusty
Consider a guided tour in English for BYN38, or explore independently for less
Visit the Book Museum to see historical treasures including 16th century printed Bibles
Expect mostly suburban views from the observation deck as library is outside city center
Take advantage of the surrounding Slyapyanskaya waterway parks for photos of the building exterior
vibe: Futuristic and imposing by day, mesmerizing and otherworldly at night when the LED facade transforms the building into a glowing diamond visible for miles. The interior combines modern functionality with cultural reverence - spacious reading halls contrast with intimate museum spaces housing centuries-old manuscripts. The transparent glass elevator creates a flight-like sensation ascending to panoramic views. At night, visitors gather in surrounding parks to watch the building's spectacular color-changing light shows, creating a community atmosphere around this architectural wonder.
expectations: A stunning futuristic diamond-shaped building with unique geometric architecture
Breathtaking observation deck views of Minsk from 73 meters high
An impressive LED light show transforming the building at night
A major library with extensive collections and historical treasures
Clean, pristine viewing experience from the observation deck
Central location with easy city views
reality: The architecture is genuinely spectacular and unlike anything else in Eastern Europe
The LED light show at night absolutely delivers - over 4,646 fixtures create truly mesmerizing displays visible from miles away
The observation deck glass is often dusty/dirty, making photography challenging and views less pristine than expected
Views are mostly of suburbs since the library is located outside the city center
The observation deck visit is brief - most spend only 20 minutes maximum
The Book Museum genuinely contains remarkable historical items including 16th century Bibles
The building is more impressive from outside than inside for most tourists
The surrounding parks provide the best vantage points for appreciating the building
Access requires your passport for entry to main areas
unique_facts: The shape is a rhombicuboctahedron - an Archimedean solid that was relatively unknown when the building was constructed in 2006
Weighs 115,000 tonnes (not including books) and stands on 22 floors
The only structure in Minsk with a public observation deck since 2009
Houses a media center with over 20,000 vinyl records
Features special workstations designed for blind, visually handicapped, and physically disabled visitors
The transparent glass elevator ascends along the outer wall creating a unique 'flight' experience
A wall inscribed with a biblical phrase in various languages greets visitors at the entrance
Has a restaurant at the top serving traditional Belarusian cuisine
The LED system can produce over 65,000 different colors across 20+ light effect schemes
Featured in '100 Most Surprising Achievements of Modern Architecture' alongside Antoni Gaudi's works
surprises: It's nicknamed the 'Diamond of Knowledge' and truly sparkles like a gem at night
The building functions as an International Meeting Center hosting heads of state - not just a library
The architects solved the nighttime illumination challenge by hiding LED sources behind glass panels rather than using external floodlights
You can watch the spectacular LED shows for free from the surrounding parks - locals gather to enjoy the displays
The building contains 421,600 cubic meters of space - far larger than it appears
It's constructed from heat-reflecting glass and aluminum, making it energy efficient despite the LED displays
The observation deck has binoculars arranged around the perimeter for viewing distant locations
The high-speed elevator has completely transparent glass walls for dramatic views during ascent
Despite being a library, it's become more of a tourist attraction for its architecture and light shows than its book collection
The building sits within a series of beautiful parks pierced by the Slyapyanskaya waterway, creating a scenic setting
